{{Economic systems sidebar |expanded=By ideology}} {{Capitalism |expanded=Ideologies}} '''Dirigisme''' or '''dirigism''' ({{ety|fr|diriger|to direct}}) is an economic doctrine in which the state plays a strong directive role, as opposed to a merely [[Regulation|regulatory]] role, over a [[capitalist]] [[market economy]].<ref>[http://oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/dirigisme ''Dirigisme''] Oxford Dictionaries. Retrieved 25 May 2013.</ref> As an economic doctrine, dirigisme is the counterpart to [[laissez-faire]], stressing a positive role for state intervention in curbing productive inefficiencies and [[market failure]]s. Dirigiste policies often include [[indicative planning]], state-directed investment, and the use of market instruments (taxes and subsidies).
The term emerged in the [[Aftermath of World War II|post-war]] era to describe the economic policies of [[France]], which included substantial state-directed investment, the use of [[Indicative planning|indicative economic planning]] to supplement the [[market mechanism]], and the establishment of [[state enterprise]]s in strategic domestic sectors. It resulted in an unprecedented [[economic]] and [[demography|demographic]] growth, leading to the coinage of the term ''[[Trente Glorieuses]]'' ("Thirty Glorious [years]").
The term has subsequently been used to classify other economies that pursued similar policies, most notably the [[Four Asian Tigers|East Asian tiger economies]], and more recently the economy of the [[People's Republic of China]].<ref name="Models of dirigisme in East Asia: perspectives from Eastern Europe, 1996">''Models of dirigisme in East Asia: perspectives from Eastern Europe'', by Dragsbæk Schmidt, Johannes. 1996. Between Western Europe and East Asia, p. 196-216, {{ISBN|0333666046}}</ref> A related concept is [[state capitalism]].
Most modern economies can be characterized as ''dirigiste'' to some degree – for instance, the state may exercise directive action by performing or subsidizing research and development of new technologies, through government procurement (especially [[military]]) or through state-run research institutes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publicfinanceinternational.org/features/2013/06/the-myth-of-the-meddling-state-nothing-ventured/ |title=The Myth of the "Meddling" State |author=Mariana Mazzucato |date=June 25, 2013 |publisher=Public Finance International |accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref>
==In France== {{refimprove section|date=May 2013}} Before the [[Second World War]], France had a relatively fragmented [[capitalism|capitalist]] economic system. The many small companies, often family-owned, were often not dynamic and efficient{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} in comparison to the large industrial groups in [[Germany]] or the [[United States]]. The Second World War laid waste to France. Railroads and industries were destroyed by aerial [[bombardment]] and [[sabotage]]; industries were seized by Nazi Germany; in the immediate postwar years loomed the spectre of long years of [[rationing]] (such as the one enforced in the [[United Kingdom]]). Some sections of the French business and political world lost authority after [[Vichy France|collaborating with the German occupiers]].
Post-war French governments, from whichever political side, generally sought rational, efficient economic development, with the long-term goal of matching the highly developed and technologically advanced economy of the [[United States]]. The development of French dirigisme coincided with the development of [[meritocracy|meritocratic]] [[Technocracy (bureaucratic)|technocracy]]: the [[École Nationale d'Administration]] supplied the state with high-level administrators, while leadership positions in industry were staffed with [[Corps of Mines (France)|Corps of Mines]] state engineers and other personnel trained at the [[École Polytechnique]].
During the 1945–1975 period, France experienced unprecedented [[economic growth]] (5.1% on average) and a [[demography|demographic]] boom, leading to the coinage of the term ''[[Trente Glorieuses]]'' ("Thirty Glorious [years]").
Dirigisme flourished under the [[right-wing|centre-right]] governments of [[Charles de Gaulle]] and [[Georges Pompidou]]. In those times, the policy was viewed as a middle way between the American policy of little state involvement and the Soviet policy of total state control. In 1981, [[French Socialist Party|Socialist]] president [[François Mitterrand]] was elected, promising greater [[state enterprise]] in the economy; his government soon [[nationalization|nationalised]] industries and banks. However, in 1983 the initial bad economic results forced the government to renounce dirigisme and start the era of ''rigueur'' ("rigour"). Dirigisme has remained out of favour with subsequent governments, though some of its traits remain.
===Indicative planning=== The main French tool under dirigisme was [[indicative planning]] through plans designed by the ''Commissariat général du plan'' ("Commission for the Plan"). Indicative planning used various incentives to induce public and private actors to behave in an optimal fashion, with the plan serving as a general guideline for optimal investment. During this period France never ceased to be a capitalist economy directed by the [[accumulation of capital]], profit-maximizing enterprise and [[Market economy|market-based allocation]] of producer goods.
In contrast to [[Soviet-type economic planning|Soviet-type central planning]] practiced in the former [[Eastern bloc|Soviet bloc]], where economic planning substituted market allocation and operated the factors of production according to a binding plan, the French state never owned more than a minority of industry and did not seek to replace markets with planning. The idea of dirigisme is to complement and improve the efficiency of the market through indirect planning intended to provide better information to market participants. This concept is held in contrast to a planned economy, which aims to replace market-based allocation of production and investment with a binding plan of production expressed in units of physical quantities.
===State ownership=== Because French industry prior to the Second World War was weak due to fragmentation, the French government encouraged mergers and the formation of "[[national champions]]": large industry groups backed by the state.
Two areas where the French government sought greater control were in [[infrastructure]] and the transportation system. The French government owned the national railway company [[SNCF]], the national electricity utility [[Electricité de France|EDF]], the national natural gas utility [[Gaz de France|GDF]], the national airline [[Air France]]; [[France Télécom|phone]] and [[La Poste (France)|postal]] services were operated as the [[Postes, télégraphes et téléphones (France)|PTT]] administration. The government chose to devolve the construction of most [[Freeway|autoroutes]] (freeways) to semi-private companies rather than to administer them itself. Other areas where the French government directly intervened were defense, nuclear and aerospace industries ([[Aérospatiale]]).
This development was marked by ''volontarisme'', the belief that difficulties (e.g. postwar devastation, lack of natural resources) could be overcome through willpower and ingenuity. For instance, following the [[1973 energy crisis]], the saying "In France we don't have oil, but we have ideas" was coined. Volontarisme emphasized [[modernization]], resulting in a variety of ambitious state plans. Examples of this trend include the extensive use of [[nuclear power|nuclear energy]] (close to 80% of French electrical consumption), the [[Minitel]], an early online system for the masses, and the [[TGV]], a [[high-speed rail]] network.
==Other economies with dirigiste characteristics== Economic dirigisme has been described as an inherent aspect of [[fascist]] economies by Hungarian author, [[Iván T. Berend]] in his book ''An Economic History of Twentieth-Century Europe''.<ref>[[Iván T. Berend]], An Economic History of Twentieth-Century Europe, Cambridge University Press, 2005, p. 93</ref> However, the Fascist systems created by [[Benito Mussolini]] ([[Italy]]), [[António de Oliveira Salazar|António Salazar]] ([[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Portugal]]), [[Francisco Franco]] ([[Spain]]) and [[Adolf Hitler]] ([[Germany]]) are a varied mix of elements from numerous philosophies, including: [[nationalism]], [[authoritarianism]], [[militarism]], [[corporatism]], [[collectivism]], [[totalitarianism]], and [[anti-communism]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Baker|first=David|date=June 2006|title=The political economy of fascism: Myth or reality, or myth and reality?|journal=New Political Economy|volume=11|issue=2|pages=227–250|doi=10.1080/13563460600655581}}</ref>
Dirigisme has been brought up as a politico-economic scheme at odds with ''laissez-faire'' capitalism in the context of French overseas holdings. Countries such as Lebanon and Syria have been influenced by this motif<ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=4&article_id=86003 The Daily Star] - 'Youssef Chaitani's 'Post-Colonial Syria and Lebanon' chronicles the history of division between the neighbors', 17 October 2007</ref> to varying degrees throughout the post-colonial period.
The economies of the East Asian tigers are sometimes characterised as being "dirigiste" due to the strong role played by the state in [[Developmental state|development planning]] and guiding investment.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}. Dirigisme is also seen in [[India]]. The state has complete control and ownership of railways; majority control and stake in banking, insurance, electricity, and oil and gas industries; and has substantial control over telecommunication, port and shipping industries.<ref name="EnergyStats2016">{{cite web|title=Energy Statistics 2017|url=http://www.mospi.gov.in/sites/default/files/publication_reports/Energy_Statistics_2017.pdf|website=mospi.nic.in|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="factual">{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/2007/09/01001100/India-growth-story-is-attracti.html|title= India growth story is attracting talent from govt establishments|newspaper=Mint|date=1 September 2007|first=Jeetha|last=D'Silva|accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="SCIabout">{{cite web|url=http://www.shipindia.com/newsite/DisplayContent.asp?CategoryID=1&ContentID=1|title=About Us|work=Official webpage of the Shipping Corporation of India|accessdate=3 June 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071106162636/http://www.shipindia.com/newsite/DisplayContent.asp?CategoryID=1&ContentID=1 |archivedate = 6 November 2007}}</ref><ref name="test">[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-07-27/news/29820591_1_par-with-private-insurers-sovereign-guarantee-policies], Sovereign guarantee for all policies issued by LIC will continue.</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Earl Hagaman | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=NZL|CNZM|size=100%}} | image = File:Earl Hagaman (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Hagaman in 2014 | birth_name = Earl Raymond Hagaman | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1925|09|12}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], US | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2017|05|25|1925|09|12}} | death_place = [[Christchurch]], New Zealand | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Hotel operator | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Earl Raymond Hagaman''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|CNZM}} (12 September 1925 – 25 May 2017) was an American-born New Zealand hotel operator.
==Biography== Hagaman was born in [[Los Angeles]] on 12 September 1925.<ref name="2014 Press profile">{{cite news |last1=Matthews |first1=Philip |title=Hagamans building an empire |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/christchurch-life/9725378/Hagamans-building-an-empire |accessdate=25 May 2017 |work=[[The Press]] |date=16 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://search.ancestry.com.au/cgi-bin/sse.dll?indiv=try&db=cabirth1905&h=1208450 |title=California birth index, 1905–1995 |year=2005 |website= |publisher=Ancestry.com Operations |accessdate=25 May 2017 |subscription=yes}}</ref> From 1961 to March 1981, he was married to Barbara Jean Fairbank.<ref name="Barbara Fairbank">{{cite news |last1=van Beynen |first1=Martin |title=Former wife 'not pursuing estate'<!-- Print title shown; online title was: "Earl Hagaman's ex-wife not pursuing estate 'at the moment'" --> |url= https://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/94581274/earl-hagamans-exwife-not-pursuing-estate-at-the-moment |accessdate=12 July 2017 |work=[[The Press]] |date=12 July 2017 |page=A3}}</ref> He moved to New Zealand in 1983<ref name="Barbara Fairbank" /> after visiting his friend Ralph Brown, who had moved to New Zealand in 1972. Brown and Hagaman invested in hotels and out of this venture, Scenic Group developed.<ref name="2014 Press profile" /> At the time of his death, Hagaman's hotel empire employed around 1000 staff.<ref>{{cite news |title=Earl Hagaman, multi-millionaire businessman who sued Andrew Little, has died |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11863022 |accessdate=25 May 2017 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=25 May 2017}}</ref> In 1989, Hagaman bought the house of Sir [[Robertson Stewart]] in the [[Christchurch]] suburb of [[Ilam, New Zealand|Ilam]], and lived there for the rest of his life. The house had a 2007 rating valuation of just under NZ$4m.<ref name="2014 Press profile" />
In the [[2014 New Year Honours (New Zealand)|2014 New Year Honours]], Hagaman was appointed a [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] for services to business, tourism and philanthropy.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/publications/new-year-honours-list-2014 | title=New Year honours list 2014|date=31 December 2013 | publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet | accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
Hagaman was in his 60s when he hired a financial controller for Scenic Group; she was in her early 20s. Hagaman's fourth marriage was failing and he later married his employee – Lani Hagaman.<ref name="2014 Press profile" /> They had three children together, and Hagaman had four children from prior relationships.<ref name="Stuff obit">{{cite news |title=High-profile hotel magnate Earl Hagaman dies, aged 92 |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/92961749/highprofile-hotel-magnate-earl-hagaman-dies-aged-92 |accessdate=25 May 2017 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |date=25 May 2017}}</ref> Earl and Lani Hagaman's wealth was estimated by the ''[[National Business Review]]'' at [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]180m.<ref name="2014 Press profile" />
The Hagamans were large donors to various causes, including [[St. Andrew's College, Christchurch|St. Andrew's College]] (NZ$250k), [[ChristChurch Cathedral, Christchurch|ChristChurch Cathedral]], the [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]], and the [[ACT New Zealand|ACT Party]].<ref name="2014 Press profile" /> The Hagamans have donated more than NZ$10m.<ref name="Stuff obit" /> The Hagamans sued [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] leader [[Andrew Little (New Zealand politician)|Andrew Little]] for defamation and sought $2.3m in damages. Whilst Little was found guilty of defaming Earl Hagaman on one count, the jury could not decide on all other claims, and the High Court judge thus let all claims retire. Shortly after the verdict in April 2017, Lani Hagaman declared that she would seek a retrial.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Walls |first1=Jason |title=Lani Hagaman will continue to pursue Little in court for defamation |url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/lani-hagaman-will-continue-pursue-little-court-defamation-jw-201874 |accessdate=25 May 2017 |work=[[National Business Review]] |date=12 April 2017}}</ref> Lani Hagaman laid an appeal in September 2017, after her husband had died. She must overcome the legal hurdle that according to the Law Reform Act 1936, a defamation case cannot continue after a person's death. Her lawyers argue that the case had already been heard, and they want to test whether the trial judge advised the jury correctly on the point of qualified privilege that [[member of parliament|members of parliament]] enjoy speaking inside [[New Zealand Parliament|Parliament]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hutching |first1=Chris |title=Hagaman defamation suit heat still on as widow continues fight <!-- Lani Hagaman seeks Court of Appeal direction in Andrew Little defamation case--> |url= https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/97251896/lani-hagaman-seeks-appeal-court-direction-in-little-defamation-case |accessdate=8 October 2017 |work=[[The Press]] |date=27 September 2017 |page=A1}}</ref>
In 2010, property claims by his former wife Fairbanks appeared in the Christchurch [[High Court of New Zealand|High Court]] after having previously been filed in a [[California superior courts|Californian superior court]]. The Christchurch court was tasked by the Californian court to take evidence from eight witnesses including Hagaman himself. Six of the witnesses refused and the case went to the [[Court of Appeal of New Zealand]], which upheld the request.<ref name="Barbara Fairbank" /> Hagaman died at his home on 25 May 2017. He was survived by his wife, their children, and the four children from previous relationships.<ref name="Stuff obit" /> In Hagaman's will, NZ$1.5m is set aside for some of his children that can only be distributed once Hagaman's trustees consider that all claims by Fairbank have been settled.<ref name="Barbara Fairbank" />

{{Infobox person | name = Erna Low | image = | alt = | caption = Low skiing on one of her trips to the mountains | birth_name = Lӧwe | birth_date = 28 July 1909 | birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | death_date = 12 February 2002 | death_place = [[London]] | nationality = Austrian | other_names = | known_for = Ski Travel Industry Innovation | occupation = Businesswoman
}}
'''Erna Low''' (28 July 1909 – 12 February 2002) was an [[Austria]]n [[Jewish]] businesswoman who settled in England and is best known for her work in the ski travel industry.
Low has been cited as a pioneer in the development of the [[package holiday]]<ref>{{cite journal|title=Pioneer of the package holiday|journal=Ski|date=September 1978|volume=43|issue=1|pages=135}}</ref> and was the founder of [http://www.ernalow.co.uk/ Erna Low] Travel Services Ltd. She worked in the holiday industry for over sixty years. She retired in 1995.
==Early years==
Low was born in [[Vienna]] in 1909 as the only daughter of Eduard Carl Lӧwe and his wife Emma.<ref>{{cite book|last=Frary|first=Mark|title=Aiming High|year=2013|publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd|isbn=1780883544|pages=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nnFHlhoQmLwC&pg=PP1&dq=aiming+high+frary}}</ref> She remained in the city throughout her childhood and education.
She became the [[Austria]]n [[javelin throw|javelin]] champion<ref>{{cite news|title=A talented athlete|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> before moving to [[England]] in 1931, with ten borrowed pounds in her pocket, to research a [[PhD]] thesis on [[Lord de Tabley]], a Victorian poet and botanist. During her studies, Low traced the grandchildren of de Tabley and was invited to stay at the family home in [[Knutsford]], [[Cheshire]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Low invited to meet Lord de Tabley's family|newspaper=The Times|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
While living in [[Bloomsbury]], Low earned a basic living as a language tutor, but decided that she needed to earn more to finance trips back to [[Austria]] to visit her sick mother and fulfil her passion for [[skiing]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's desire to travel home|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
Low's business career in the travel industry began in 1932 when she placed an advertisement in the ''[[Morning Post]]''. It read:
'[[Winter Sports]] – [[Austria]], fortnight, £15 only, including rail and hotel, arranged by young Viennese Graduette for young people leaving [[Christmas]].'<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's first advert|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
Low set up a permanent home in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and became a citizen in 1940, changing her name from Lӧwe to Low in the process.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low changes her name|newspaper=The Independent|date=18 February 2002}}</ref>
== War Years ==
The outbreak of [[World War II]] made ski trips to [[Austria]] impossible, so Low planned alternative visits to [[Switzerland]].
For much of the war she worked for the [[BBC]] in [[Worcestershire]] where she would monitor German broadcasts for the Intelligence Service,<ref>{{cite news|title=Working for the BBC|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> but she disliked this role and chose to become a lecturer in the [[Army Education Corps]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Erna Low's occupation during the war|url=http://www.ernalow.co.uk/about-us-history|publisher=Erna Low}}</ref>
She then developed the 'house-party' concept. Low recognised that families were separated by war service and offered the opportunity for people to meet one another at [[Christmas]]. She leased [[boarding school]]s and invited paying guests to stay.<ref>{{cite news|title=The 'house party'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> This venture became a company in 1946 and was later known as Enjoy Britain Ltd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Enjoy Britain Ltd.|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
== 1947 – 1979: Erna Low Travel Service ==
In 1947, Low set up Erna Low Travel Service Ltd out of Reece Mews, South Kensington.<ref>[http://www.lurotbrand.co.uk/flipbook/mewsnews2010-winter/ Mews News]. ''Lurot Brand. ''Published Winter 2010. Page 5. Retrieved 16 September 2013.</ref>
She worked with schools to run school courses<ref>{{cite journal|title=Low runs school trips|journal=Climber and Rambler|year=1970|volume=9}}</ref> and utilised the post-war demand for foreign travel to develop holidays for which the majority was paid before departure. A foreign exchange allowance of £50 meant that travel experts were in demand and Low's company provided this.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low takes advantage of the foreign exchange allowance|newspaper=The Times|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
Low was very adept at finding new resorts for her clients in both the summer and winter market.<ref>{{cite news|title=The 'house party'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=February 14, 2002}}</ref> Erna Low's 1948 brochure said: “[[Winter sports]] are on the map again”<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's view of winter sports|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/feb/27/guardianobituaries2|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 February 2002}}</ref> and by 1950, it included 24 continental trips.<ref>{{cite news|title=Erna Low Travel Service Ltd expands|newspaper=The Independent|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref> Low placed emphasis on the personal touch and until the mid-1950s, she accompanied each group on their trip.<ref>{{cite web|title=Erna Low's personal touch|url=http://www.ernalow.co.uk/about-us-history|publisher=Erna Low}}</ref>
An all-inclusive fortnight in a first-class hotel with Erna Low cost 38 guineas<ref>{{cite news|title=The all-inclusive holiday|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> and after the introduction of [[charter flights]] in 1954, she even reduced costs by advising her clients to travel in ski clothes to save on excess baggage expenses.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's eye for value|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=February 14, 2002}}</ref>
Weekend train trips to [[Austria]] became a regular feature in this period of the company's development and customers were provided with a music carriage for entertainment during their 24-hour rail journey on the 'snow train'.<ref>{{cite news|title=The 'Snow Train'|newspaper=The Independent|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
Low's business continued to grow and in 1972, with a staff of sixty and a turnover of £1.5 million, she opted to sell.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low sells the company|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> She bought her name back in 1975 with the business struggling, but sold again in 1979 to become a consultant to the travel industry.
== Late career ==
Low reinvented her company in 1981 under the name Erna Low Consultants Ltd. In this role, Low concentrated on developing the health spa market throughout [[Europe]]. She became the official representative in the [[UK]] of resorts at [[La Plagne]], [[Les Arcs]] and [[Flaine]], while she was decorated for her services to tourism by [[France]], [[Italy]] and [[Austria]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's honours|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
Low continued to work in the 1990s and gained membership of the [[Chartered Institute of Marketing]] for her feasibility study on [[Strathpeffer]]. She was also the vice-president of both the Kensington Chamber of Commerce and Women of the Year Association, and won a 'Women Mean Business' award at the age of 83.<ref>{{cite news|title=Responsibilities|newspaper=The Times|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
Low handed control of the company to her successor and loyal employee, Joanna Yellowlees-Bound, in 1995.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low hands over the company|newspaper=The Independent|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
In May 2000, the company was entered into the British Travel Industry's 'Hall of Fame'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Entry into the 'Hall of Fame'|url=http://www.ernalow.co.uk/about-us-history|publisher=Erna Low}}</ref>
== Personal life == Low was renowned for her formidable style, and she was never known to avoid confrontation. On one occasion, a senior executive with a rival company won an award at a trade ceremony. Clearly bitter at a setback earlier in his career, he said: “You once refused to employ me, and look where I am now.” Low's response provided an insight into the way in which she worked. “I still wouldn't employ you,” she said.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low's confrontation with a former employee|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
Low was a consummate networker and taught royalty, actors and politicians to ski.
Despite her often intimidating façade, Low made many friends through business and while travelling. She was the godmother to a number of children, including the actress [[Emily Lloyd]], following a friendship with her grandmother, Uli Lloyd-Pack who worked for Low for over 30 years, and Uli Lloyd-Pack’s son, [[Roger Lloyd-Pack]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Friendship with the Lloyd-Pack family|newspaper=The Times|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref>
Low never married and chose to live alone in [[South Kensington]] with her dog.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low lived alone|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1384767/Erna-Low.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 February 2002}}</ref>
== Death ==
Low died at the age of 92 on 12 February 2002 at her home in [[London]].
== The Future of Erna Low Ltd ==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:MarkFraryAimingHigh.jpg|right | thumb| The cover of Mark Frary's book]] -->
The company continues to operate in the ski industry with Low's principles forming an integral part of Erna Low's identity under the direction of Joanna Yellowlees-Bound. The company, still based in the mews house in South Kensington from where Miss Low lived and worked, has since branched out into real estate and has a successful property company, Erna Low Property, with an office in Arc 1950, in the French Alps.
Erna Low Ltd marked the 80th-year anniversary of Low's ''[[Morning Post]]'' advertisement in 2012<ref>{{cite web|title=Erna Low Ltd Anniversary|url=http://www.ernalow.co.uk/80|publisher=Erna Low}}</ref> and Mark Frary's biography, ''Aiming High'',<ref>{{cite book|last=Frary|first=Mark|title=Aiming High|year=2012|publisher=Troubador Publishing|isbn=9781780883540}}</ref> was launched at the [[Coronet Cinema]] in [[London]] on 11 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anniversary Event|url=http://blog.ernalow.co.uk/2012/11/video-from-the-erna-low-80th-anniversary-event/|publisher=Erna Low}}</ref>
In addition to this, Erna Low Ltd produced a short film of Low’s life from many thousands of hours of archive cine films.<ref>{{cite web|title=Archive Films|url=http://www.ernalow.co.uk/archive-videos|publisher=Erna Low|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref>

[[John Zochonis|Sir John Zochonis]] (great nephew) | website = }} '''George Basil Zochonis''' (1852–1929) was a Greek businessman, who was the founder of [[PZ Cussons]], one of the [[United Kingdom]]'s largest personal health care and consumer goods manufacturing businesses. ==Career== Brought up in [[Greece]], George Zochnis initially joined the trading house of ''Fisher & Randall'' in [[Freetown]] in [[Sierra Leone]].[http://www.mosi.org.uk/media/33870627/patersonzochonis.pdf Paterson Zochonis: History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110112213702/http://www.mosi.org.uk/media/33870627/patersonzochonis.pdf |date=2011-01-12 }} In 1879, together with [[George Paterson (businessman)|George Paterson]], he founded [[PZ Cussons|Paterson Zochonis]] and built it into a large trading house. It imported West African goods ([[Arecaceae|palm products]], [[nut (fruit)|nut]]s etc.) into the [[United Kingdom]] and then exported them to [[Europe]]. It also exported [[United Kingdom|British]] goods ([[textiles]] etc.) to West Africa. He died in 1929. After his death control of the business passed to Constantine Zochonis, his [[nephew]], and then more recently, to John Zochonis (Constantine's [[son]]).[http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/business/s/212/212612_sir_john_zochonis.html Sir John Zochonis] Manchester Evening News, 9 May 2006 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zochnis, George}} [[Category:1852 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Zochonis family|George]] {{UK-business-bio-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=June 2014}} A '''guaranteed rental''' is a transaction whereby a party looking to acquire a property in order to rent it out on a retail basis (i.e., nightly or weekly), typically a [[property manager]] or [[vacation rental]] manager, rents from the owner of the property a large block of time, typically several months or even years. Through the transaction the acquirer provides the owner of the property with a guaranteed sum over the term of the contract. The acquirer then has the right to rent the property in question out on a retail basis, keeping all related revenues. This transaction is popular with parties seeking to shift the risk and/or management burden associated with renting property.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/investing/buy-to-let/10718950/Landlords-warned-of-rental-guarantee-pitfalls.html Landlords warned of 'rental guarantee' pitfalls], "The Telegraph". Web. 02 June 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/money/spend-save/can-guaranteed-rental-schemes-save-struggling-landlords-1776031.html Can guaranteed rental schemes save struggling landlords?], "The Independent UK". Web. 02 June 2014.</ref> Such a transaction is similar to [[leaseback]] arrangements more frequently used by [[property developers]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=E9Amkpj-AIQC&pg=PA441&lpg=PA441&dq=developer+lease+back+property+after+sale+guarantee+rental+income&source=bl&ots=a7RWedACvt&sig=1dN0qpu3jaAenAIavphxvR1BBZE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pCKOU9qVL5ffsAScmILABw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=developer%20lease%20back%20property%20after%20sale%20guarantee%20rental%20income&f=false], Ratcliffe, John, Michael Stubbs, and Miles Keeping. Urban Planning and Real Estate Development. Routledge, Jan 19, 2009, p. 440-441.</ref> == Benefits and risks of wholesale rentals ==
=== Property owners ===
Through a wholesale contract a property owner is able to receive a guaranteed sum over the term of the contract. This takes the risk out of trying to rent the property him or herself, often with financial discount. Depending on how the contract is structured, the property owner may also shift more or less of the costs, maintenance, repairs, and other property owner responsibilities to the acquirer during the term of the contract. One potential downside is that by selling the right to rent to a third party, the homeowner loses some control over how that property is managed during the term, though this can also be negotiated and agreed within the contract.<ref>[http://www.streetdirectory.com/travel_guide/75053/property_tips/free_advice_on_guaranteed_property_rental_schemes.html], "Street Directory". Web. 03 June 2014.</ref>
=== Property managers ===
Through a wholesale contract a property manager is able to acquire new inventory to manage on a retail basis, increasing revenues. When acquired at the right price, such contracts can also increase profit margins. By purchasing the weeks during the term, the manager has increased control over how the property is managed. One potential downside is the increased risk of providing a guarantee - if the property does not rent as well as predicted in the retail market, the manager still is obligated to pay the property owner the agreed upon sum.<ref>[http://www.propertyangel.in/blog/types-of-property-management-companies], "PropertyAngel.in". Web. 03 June 2014.</ref> == Types of guaranteed rental contracts ==
=== Bilateral contracts ===
Wholesale rentals can be negotiated directly between homeowners and property managers. Such contracts can be good where the parties trust one another, and the numbers are easily agreed upon.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=E9Amkpj-AIQC&pg=PA441&lpg=PA441&dq=developer+lease+back+property+after+sale+guarantee+rental+income&source=bl&ots=a7RWedACvt&sig=1dN0qpu3jaAenAIavphxvR1BBZE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pCKOU9qVL5ffsAScmILABw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=developer%20lease%20back%20property%20after%20sale%20guarantee%20rental%20income&f=false], Ratcliffe, John, Michael Stubbs, and Miles Keeping. Urban Planning and Real Estate Development. Routledge, Jan 19, 2009, p. 440-441.</ref> === Marketplaces ===
Property owners and property managers can also come to terms through wholesale rental marketplaces. Through such marketplaces property managers compete against one another, bidding up the price offered and ultimately paid to property owners. By creating a market-derived price for properties’ rental weeks, such marketplaces often make it quick and easy for property owners and property managers to come to agreement and sign wholesale rental contracts.<ref name=tnooz>[http://www.tnooz.com/article/Vacation-Futures-wholesale-vacation-rental-marketplace# Startup pitch: Vacation Futures creates the wholesale vacation rental marketplace], "tnooz". Web. 02 June 2014.</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=April 2010}} {{underlinked|date=February 2013}} }} [[Image:BusinessofGovernment Logo.jpg|thumb|IBM Center for The Business of Government logo]]
The '''[[ibm.com|IBM]] Center for The Business of Government''' produces and disseminates thought leadership that focuses on public management issues facing government executives at all levels. According to its mission statement, the center seeks to connect public management research to practice in order to improve government effectiveness and performance. It does this by funding independent third-party research,<ref>{{cite web|last=Kelman|first=Steve|title=How IBM supports academic research on the business of government|url=http://fcw.com/blogs/lectern/2012/06/chenok-ibm-center.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> publishing a bi-annual magazine, producing a weekly radio interview program,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government Hour|url=http://www.federalnewsradio.com/?nid=159|publisher=FederalNewsRadio.com|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> convening discussions with practitioners and academics, and hosting forums and various blogs and other online content.
==History== The center was originally formed in 1998 as the [[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]] Endowment for The Business of Government. When IBM acquired the management consulting arm of PriceWaterhouseCoopers in 2002, it was renamed. The center is led by Executive Director Dan Chenok,<ref>{{cite web|last=Weigelt|first=Matthew|title=Dan Chenok to take reins at IBM think tank|url=http://fcw.com/articles/2012/06/04/chenok-breul-ibm.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> a former career federal executive for information policy and technology at the [[Office of Management and Budget]] (OMB).
The IBM Center for The Business of Government is one of several dozen [[good government]] organizations located in Washington, D.C. that provide context and offer insights and practical, actionable recommendations that address federal government mission and management challenges.
== Research and publications == The IBM center includes in its name “Business of Government” to emphasize its focus on the management and operation—not the policies—of government. It seeks to “bridge the gap” between research and practice by helping to stimulate and accelerate the production of actionable research.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Journal of Public Administration, Research and Theory|volume=21|issue=suppl1|pages=i99-i112}}</ref>
"Unlike traditional scholarly outlets, the IBM Center makes explicitly clear that its reports are to be ‘written for government executives and managers’ and that in making the decision to fund research proposals, it looks for very practical findings and recommendations—not just theory and concepts—in order to assist executives and managers to more effectively respond to mission and management challenges." <ref>Journal of Public Administration, Research and Theory, Volume 21, Issue (suppl 1) pp. i99-i112</ref>
Since its inception, the IBM Center for The Business of Government has published more than 250 research reports and books in areas such as public sector management and performance, technology and innovation, security and privacy, acquisition and procurement, and citizen engagement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hardy|first=Michael|title=The Chenok era dawns at IBM center|url=http://fcw.com/articles/2012/06/30/buzz-chenok-breul.aspx|publisher=FCW The Business of Federal Technology|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> Reports are commissioned through a competitive funding process<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Center for The Business of Government - Research Stipends Synopsis:|url=https://researchfunding.duke.edu/detail.asp?OppID=5127|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> that occurs twice a year, in the spring and fall. Funded researchers have included academics from top schools of public management and business, including Harvard University, the London School of Economics, Syracuse University and Johns Hopkins University.
== Recent research interests == * Leading in an era of complex challenges * Managing collaboration and connectivity * Using data and analytics to make better decisions * Pursuing cost savings and improving performance * Identifying acquisition approaches that engage the private sector more effectively * Managing risks and responding to threats in today’s security environment * Providing insights for the presidential transition from campaigning to governing
== Notable publications == * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/content/business-government-magazine The Business of Government Magazine]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government Magazine Spring/Summer 2012|url=http://www.federalnewsradio.com/163/2931810/The-Business-of-Government-Magazine-SpringSummer-2012|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> – This bi-annual magazine features interviews with and profiles of government leaders as well as topical articles on management issues facing public sector executives. It also provides summaries of recent reports, radio interviews and events.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Business of Government|url=http://digital.turn-page.com/i/73025/4|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/seven-management-imperatives Seven Management Imperatives] – This report identifies seven societal trends that governments will have to manage and the imperatives that will drive governments to manage differently, including performance improvement and greater collaboration with the private sector.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Center for the Business of Government publishes report on seven management imperatives for government|url=http://servicedelivery.fahcsia.gov.au/2011/08/01/ibm-center-for-the-business-of-government-publishes-report-on-seven-management-imperatives-for-government/|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/ten-challenges-facing-public-managers Ten Challenges Facing Public Managers]<ref>{{cite web|last=Longley|first=Robert|title=The Next President's Top 10 Challenges|url=http://usgovinfo.about.com/od/thepresidentandcabinet/a/prestopten.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> – This report outlines a set of management issues that government executives will face in the coming years. These are ten “big challenges” for the decade ahead that include not only fiscal concerns of the Government Accounting Office but also the role of results, the impending crisis of competence and the blurring of boundaries in delivering services.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ten Challenges in Public Management Identified for Decade Ahead|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/23781.wss#release|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [http://www.businessofgovernment.org/report/six-trends-transforming-government Six Trends Transforming Government]<ref>{{cite news|last=Davidson|first=Joe|title=Report Offers 6 Keys to a More Successful Government|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/17/AR2006091700506.html|accessdate=5 February 2013|work=The Washington Post|date=18 September 2006}}</ref> – Increasingly, the challenges facing government are more complex and face a new set of imperatives for success. This report identifies six trends that are leading to improved government performance. These trends, often in combination with one another, make it more likely that government will be able to successfully respond to the ever-increasing and complex challenges it faces today and that it will continue to face in the future. * ''[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/book/operators-manual-new-administration Operators Manual]'' ''for the Next Administration'' and ''[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/book/getting-it-done-guide-government-executives Getting It Done]'' – The handbook, ''Operator’s Manual for the Next Administration'', is aimed at senior management, while ''Getting It Done'' is billed as a guide for government executives. The books offer tips on managing the confirmation process, learning about federal agencies and how they work, assembling a leadership team, and developing a vision and an agenda.<ref>{{cite web|title=Center for The Business of Government Lays Out Key Imperatives for Managing the Presidential Transition and Governing in a New Administration|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/25375.wss|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref>
==''The Business of Government Hour''== For more than a decade, the weekly radio program ''The Business of Government Hour''<ref>[http://www.businessofgovernment.org/interviews ''The Business of Government Hour'']</ref> has interviewed government executives who are changing the way government does business. As a platform for government executives to discuss their careers, agencies and agency accomplishments, as well as their vision of government in the 21st century, the program provides a forum for government leaders to highlight key initiatives, management challenges and successes.
''The Business of Government Hour'' has interviewed more than 300 government executives from deputy secretaries to C-Suite executives from a range of federal agencies, as well as state and local government executives. The show has interviewed such government executives and thought leaders as Admiral [[Thad Allen]], Dr. [[Francis Collins]], Dr. [[Anthony Fauci]], Governor [[Tim Kaine]], Dr. [[Raymond Orbach]], Dr. [[Robert Braun]], Dr. [[Kathleen Merrigan]], General [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]], General [[James R. Clapper|James Clapper]], [[Robert F. Hale]], [[David M. Walker (U.S. Comptroller General)|David Walker]], [[Eugene Louis Dodaro|Gene Dodaro]], [[Michael J. Astrue|Michael Astrue]], Ambassador [[Elizabeth Frawley Bagley]], [[Craig Fugate]], [[Alec Ross (innovator)|Alec Ross]], Tom Allen, General [[Anthony Zinni|Tony Zinni]] and Professor [[Joseph Nye]].
== Presidential transition activities == The center’s “Governing in the Next Four Years” series, which examines issues facing the new presidential term, continues a series of transition-related materials that began with several publications in 2004{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} and continued in 2007, when Center Senior Fellow John Kamensky began writing a Presidential Transition blog<ref>{{cite web|last=Kamensky|first=John|title=The Presidential Transition|url=http://transition2008.wordpress.com/|publisher=IBM|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> that has been cited in the US and overseas.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Conference on Administrative Development Towards Excellence in Public Sector Performance|url=http://www.fifty.ipa.edu.sa/conf/customcontrols/paperworkflash/Content/pdf/m1/en/7.pdf|publisher=Saudi Arabia Institute of Public Administration|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rollins|first=John|title=2008-2009 Presidential Transition: National Security Considerations and Options|url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RL34456.pdf|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ogden|first=Benjamin|title=The United States Drug Enforcement Administration: Pertaining to Public Safety and Homeland Security|url=http://digitalcommons.pace.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1009&context=homelandsecurity|publisher=Pace University|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Inauguration: Online Resources|url=http://burma.usembassy.gov/uploads/images/BLh5yEhDh-lDstCR-2-_VQ/InaugurationOnlineResources.pdf|publisher=The American Center|accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref>
== The IBM Center Blog == Articles written by center staff and posted to their blog are often syndicated, excerpted or quoted in government-oriented media platforms, such as AOL Gov,<ref>[http://gov.aol.com/ AOL Gov]</ref> Government Executive,<ref>[http://www.govexec.com/ Government Executive]</ref> Federal Times,<ref>[http://www.federaltimes.com/ Federal Times]</ref> Federal Computer Week,<ref>[http://fcw.com/Home.aspx Federal Computer Week]</ref> and Government Computer News.<ref>[http://gcn.com/Home.aspx Government Computer News]</ref>

'''Ian Lenagan''' (born 1946, Scholes, [[Wigan]]) is a business entrepreneur, theatre producer and shareholder of [[London Broncos]], chairman and owner of [[Wigan Warriors]], and former owner of [[Oxford United F.C.]] In 2016 he was appointed Chairman of the [[Football League]].
==Early life==
Born in Scholes, Wigan, Lenagan attended St Patrick's Primary School as a child and gained an appreciation for [[rugby league]], playing for the local amateur club also named St Patrick's.
He was educated at West Park Grammar School in St Helens before eventually moving onto university. Lenagan attended both [[Manchester University|Manchester]] and [[Liverpool University|Liverpool]] universities and graduated with a [[BSc]] in [[Mathematics]] and a [[MSc]] in [[Magnetohydrodynamics]] respectively.<ref name="Factfile - Ian Lenagan">{{cite news | title = Factfile - Ian Lenagan | url = http://www.wiganwarriors.com/news_full.asp?newsid=3376 | publisher = [[Wigan Warriors]] official website | date = 2007-10-24 | accessdate = 2007-10-25}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Career== === Workplace Systems === In 1985 Lenagan set up his own business, Workplace Systems, in [[Milton Keynes]], to develop and supply [[software]] products for workforce management. Following its first successful contract with [[Asda]], the business became very successful and expanded abroad to places across Europe, Australasia, the US and the Middle East. Major retailers known to use Workplace Systems include [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]], [[Focus (DIY)|Focus]], [[Sports Café]], [[Next (clothing)|Next]] and [[Morrisons]]. With the success of Workplace Systems, the company was floated on the [[London Stock Exchange]] in 2000 under the name Telework Systems PLC to incorporate another company founded by Lenagan in 1981, TeleWare, which focused on the telephony software products market.
A decline in the telephone market saw TeleWare sold off to its management in 2003 and the company change its name to WorkPlace Systems International plc, 49% owned by Ian Lenagan.<ref name="Company Profile - Workplace International PLC">{{cite news |title = Company Profile - Workplace International PLC |url = http://www.workplacesystemsinternational.com/about.html |publisher = Workplace Systems International |date = 2007-10-25 |accessdate = 2007-10-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930100209/http://www.workplacesystemsinternational.com/about.html |archivedate = 2007-09-30 |df = }}</ref>
In December 2011, Workplace Systems was acquired by a Lloyds Banking Group-backed management buyout, and Lenagan stepped down from his role as chairman, receiving £19m from the buyout.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/boss-of-workplace-systems-bags-19-million-from-buyout-6377110.html |title=Boss of WorkPlace Systems bags £19 million from buyout |newspaper=Evening Standard |location=London |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
=== Theatre producer === Lenagan is also a successful theatre producer, with over 30 productions to his name. His most recent [[West End Theatre|West End]] hit is a co-production of ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' starring [[Christian Slater]].
=== Rugby league and football clubs === Lenagan is a huge [[rugby league]] fan. His successful business ventures have allowed him to become involved in the sport and in July 2005 he took over as chairman and majority shareholder of [[London Broncos#2006–2011: Harlequins Rugby League|Harlequins RL]], buying 65% of the shares and also taking a place on the board of directors. He also became a major shareholder in [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], who were controlled by long-time friend [[Nick Merry]]. In July 2012 he replaced Kelvin Thomas as chairman of the League Two club.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18826760 |title=Oxford United chairman Kelvin Thomas to leave role |date=13 July 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> Lenagan sold his interest in Oxford United and left the board in 2016 when he was appointed Chairman of the Football League.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oufc.co.uk//news/article/oxford-united-board-3135474.aspx |title=Darryl Increases Shareholding as Ian Lenagan Moves On |publisher=Oxford United F.C. |date=6 June 2016 |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
In 2007 it was announced after months of speculation that Lenagan would become the new owner of [[Wigan Warriors]] rugby league club, his boyhood team. Lenagan bought the club from former [[JJB Sports]] magnate and [[Wigan Athletic]] chairman [[Dave Whelan]]. As well as buying the club Lenagan also bought the training facilities at [[Edge Hall Road]], the former stadium of [[Orrell R.U.F.C.]] as well as a 50-year lease on the [[JJB Stadium]].<ref name="Warriors Look to Future Under New Ownership">{{cite news | title = Warriors Look to Future Under New Ownership | url = http://www.wiganwarriors.com/news_full.asp?newsid=3375 | publisher = [[Wigan Warriors]] official website | date = 2007-10-24 | accessdate = 2007-10-25 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071027034302/http://www.wiganwarriors.com/news_full.asp?newsid=3375 | archivedate = 2007-10-27}}</ref> Lenagan's first signings for Wigan were [[George Carmont]] and [[Richard Mathers|Richie Mathers]] both from the NRL and [[Karl Pryce]] who returned to rugby league from [[rugby union]] club [[Gloucester RFC|Gloucester]]. Lenagan also signed-up [[Cameron Phelps]] and [[Tim Smith (rugby league)|Tim Smith]], for the Wigan club, during the 2008 season.
=== Other businesses === Lenagan is also the non-executive chairman and 1% owner of the Sports Café, an expanding chain of sports bars and restaurants. Lenagan has recently started a new business called Animalates, a children's educational exercise club which is expected to be sold as a franchise.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}

{{For|the webcomics company|Line Webtoon}} A '''line''' is a concept in western comic books which denotes a specific couple of publications by a publisher. Sometimes taking place in a separate continuity or more loose continuity (such as [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]] by [[DC Comics]]) or exploring a kind of subject matter and or genre which the publisher does not want to involve in their main franchise or so called "universe".<ref>http://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-dark-matter-line-details/</ref> Often lines which explore more "realistic" or "dark" subject matters are published under a companies sub [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]]s (such as [[Ultimate Marvel]] or [[MAX (comics)|MAX]] by [[Marvel Comics]]) to distinguish it from their main superhero lines. Sometimes a line can be published under an imprint but not always be part of a larger continuity within their imprint (such as [[The Punisher (MAX line)|''The Punisher'' MAX line]] which is not in continuity with most other Marvel Max titles). A line can consist of several different titles, ongoing series, limited series, one-shots, annuals, specials or trades and be by many different artists but are [[advertised]] and [[marketed]] as part of the line.<ref>http://www.howtolovecomics.com/2016/10/25/resurrxion/</ref> So called crossover events are often followed by a line of tie-in comics to the event miniseries from other unrelated titles to connect them.
[[Dark Horse Comics]] has several lines which focuses on their licensed film properties such as ''[[Alien (franchise)|Alien]]'', ''[[Predator (franchise)|Predator]]'' and ''[[Star Wars]]''. The [[Aliens (Dark Horse Comics line)|''Aliens'' line]] consists only of limited series, one-shots and graphic novels due to the publishers wish to allow artistic freedom. Dark Horse's [[Star Wars (Dark Horse Comics line)|''Star Wars'' line]] was ended in 2014 due to Disney moving their [[Star Wars comics|''Star Wars'' comics]] to Marvel.<ref>https://www.newsarama.com/21137-dark-horse-s-star-wars-line-to-end-august-2014.html</ref><ref>https://gizmodo.com/the-greatest-dark-horse-star-wars-comics-to-buy-before-1670419639</ref> Dark Horse also publishes a line of comics which are creator owned but are connected through common oversight by editor [[Karen Berger]].<ref>http://www.darkhorse.com/Blog/2471/dark-horse-comics-announces-line-comics-and-graphi</ref><ref>http://www.denofgeek.com/us/books-comics/dc-entertainment/263977/dark-matter-is-dcs-new-artist-centric-comic-book-line</ref><ref>http://ew.com/books/2017/04/20/dc-comics-superstars-unite-for-new-dark-matter-line/</ref><ref>https://www.newsarama.com/23460-dc-comics-new-line-a-first-glance.html</ref><ref>http://www.seventeen.com/celebrity/movies-tv/news/a30291/dc-comics-launching-comic-book-line-for-girls/</ref><ref>http://www.cbr.com/dc-announces-full-rebirth-line-twice-monthly-books-lowered-price-point/</ref> Most companies have several simultaneously running lines.<ref>http://io9.gizmodo.com/5811314/what-you-need-to-know-about-that-huge-dc-comics-relaunch</ref><ref>https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/comics/article/58710-dark-horse-originals-line-bends-the-rules.html</ref><ref>https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/11/marvel-augmented-reality/</ref><ref>https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/11/escape-claws-why-wolverine-had-to-die-for-the-sake-of-marvel-comics/382291/</ref><ref>https://www.newsarama.com/15662-leaving-an-imprint-10-defunct-marvel-publishing-lines.html</ref>

Gallet | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 31 December 1832 | birth_place = [[La Chaux-de-Fonds]], Switzerland | death_date = 9 May 1899 | death_cause = | resting_place = La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = Swiss | other_names = | known_for = timekeeping innovations | education = | employer = | occupation = watchmaker / entrepreneur / philanthropist | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = Julien Gallet | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = Henriette Gallet-Courvoisier
Julien Gallet
Georges Gallet (1865-1946)
Louis Gallet (1873-1955) | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Léon L. Gallet''' (1832–1899), watchmaker, entrepreneur, philanthropist, and past family patriarch of the [[Gallet & Co.|Gallet Watch Company]] of Switzerland,"Gallet Watch Company History" [http://www.galletwatch.com/new_yesterday.html Gallet-hist] is considered as one of the primary architects and founders of the 19th century industrialization of the Swiss watchmaking industry. ==Life== The son of Julien Gallet (1806–1849), who moved the family watchmaking business from Geneva, Switzerland, to the manufacturing district of La Chaux-de-Fonds in 1826, Léon L. Gallet was responsible for the creation of numerous Swiss and American watch brands.Jewelers' Circular Keystone, May 17, 1899, pg. 17 Among these was the prestigious Fabrique Electa, which became the upscale line of the jewelry department at Macy’s Department store in New York City during the first quarter of the 20th century. Léon L. Gallet also established the brands National Park, Continental Watch Company, Jerome Park, Bridgeport, Eureka, Commodore, Union Square, and Lady Racine.Kathleen H. Pritchard, Swiss Timepiece Makers 1775-1975, (2 Bände), West Kennebunk 1997 While the appearance and function of many of Gallet’s timepieces were tailored to the tastes of the American consumers, all of the movements in these watches were manufactured in Switzerland. Léon Gallet played a philanthropic role in the business, cultural, and social life of his native home. As well as his prominent position as a member of both the legislature of Neuchâtel and the Council of La Chaux-de-Fonds, he was for many years, the president of the Société des Amis des Arts (Fine Arts Society) and Grand Master of the Free Masons. Together with Louis & Jules Courvoisier, Ernest Francillon of Longines, and Constant Girard-Perregaux, Léon Gallet founded the Société Intercantonale des Industries du Jura (Intercantonal Society for the Industries of the Jura Area) in 1876. The purpose of this organization was to assist in the promotion and distribution of products from Switzerland's Watch Valley while addressing the growing threat of competition in European markets from American watch manufacturers. Upon his death in 1899, Léon Gallet bequeathed a sum of 43,000 Swiss Francs (today equivalent to 1,000,000 Swiss Francs or approx. 1,000,000 US dollars) to his hometown of La Chaux-de-Fonds, of which 25,000 Swiss Francs were earmarked to build the [[Musée International d'Horlogerie]] (International Watch Making Museum).Cardinal, Catherine; Piquet, Jean-Michel (2002), Musée International d'Horlogerie, Catalogue of Selected Pieces, Switzerland: Institut l'homme et le temps, {{ISBN|2-940088-10-1}}. Donated by Léon Gallet’s son Georges, the museum’s collection was started with a body of over 100 of Gallet's most complicated and valuable timepieces, including the world's first wristwatch produced for mass consumption in 1892. The balance of the bequeathed funds was used to construct the Musée des beaux-arts de La Chaux-de-Fonds (Beaux Arts Museum of La-Chaux-de-Fonds), designed by renowned painter [[Charles l’Eplattenier]] and architect René Chapallaz, [[Le Corbusier]]'s architecture teacher. Prior to his passing, Léon Gallet commissioned René Chapallaz, to design "Villa Gallet". Situated in "Parc Gallet" in the southern part of La Chaux-de-Fonds, "Villa Gallet" still retains its original name and is considered as an important historic contribution to the Swiss [[Art Nouveau]] movement of the late 19th century.L'Inventaire Suisse d'Architecture: 1850-1920, Volume 3, Bienne, La Chaux-de-Fonds, Coire, Davos. Bern: Société d'Histoire de l'Art en Suisse. 1982. == Léon L. Gallet & The Industrialization of the Swiss Watch Industry == Any study of the 19th century industrialization of [[Switzerland]]’s “Watch Valley” is not complete without mentioning the role of watchmaker and entrepreneur, Léon L. Gallet. In the years following [[American Civil War|America’s Civil War]], a powerful shift of that country’s concentration moved from agriculture to industry. With this shift came great advancements in manufacturing as centrally located factories replaced small workshops, and large scale production of items with interchangeable parts quickly displaced less efficient hand-crafting. An immediate beneficiary of this progress was America’s watch and clock industry, as northern coal powered factories began turning out hundreds of high quality timepieces per day. On the horizon for these newly empowered companies was the inevitable expansion beyond domestic borders to embark in direct competition with the Swiss watchmaking industry. Léon L. Gallet and [[Ernest Francillon]] of [[Longines]], two Swiss watchmakers who were actively selling their wares in North America, saw the writing on the wall. Recognizing the only way that the small workshops of Switzerland’s “[[Watch Valley]]” could compete against the growing threat posed by larger American manufacturers was to unite. At the prompting of Gallet and Francillon, a new organization was created. The Société Intercantonale des Industries du Jura (Intercantonal Society of the [[Jura Mountains|Jura Industries]]) was formed to bring together the individual strengths of the region’s numerous independent watchmaking houses as a powerful cooperative entity. Yet, in spite of the formation of this new organization, the warnings of Gallet and Francillon were met with skepticism by the other members of the group. Decades of success as the world’s primary supplier of fine timepieces had resulted in a self-assured complacency within [[Switzerland]]’s watchmaking industry. Then on the 10th of May, 1876, the great [[Centennial Exposition|Philadelphia International Exhibition]], created to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the signing of [[United States Declaration of Independence|America’s Declaration of Independence]], opened to the public. Among the many displays was the indisputable evidence of the manufacturing superiority of such American companies as [[Waltham Watch Company|Waltham]] and [[Elgin National Watch Company|Elgin]], each capable of finishing many hundred watches per day. Jacques David, Swiss watchmaker and machine designer, was dispatched to America by Ernest Francillon to witness the exhibitions first-hand, and report his findings back to the Intercanonal Society. Léon L. Gallet followed shortly behind, arriving in [[Philadelphia]] the next month. What both men witnessed at the exhibition further confirmed the concerns of Gallet and Francillon. On his return to Switzerland in November, Jacques David wrote a long detailed report on the mens' findings to the Intercantonal Society of the Jura Industries. While David’s report helped to wake the Swiss watchmaking industry from its comfortable complacency, increased revenues were needed for the Society’s members to initiate the developments required to meet these new challenges. By the time that the Philadelphia Exposition opened to the public in 1876, Léon L. Gallet had already established sales offices in both [[New York City]] and [[Chicago]], going back over ten years. He had personally suffered a number of long ocean voyages to deliver his wares and to conduct business. Besides his acute knowledge of the growing threat posed by worldwide competition from US manufactures, Gallet understood the tastes of the American consumer and the opportunities the new world also held for the Jura watchmakers. With the now available joint resources from fellow manufacturing members of the Intercantonal Society, Gallet decided to take the competitive battle directly to the enemy. Not only could the rapidly expanding base of American consumers provide opportunities for increased sales of Swiss watches, these sales could provide the needed revenues to meet the expected competitive challenges in Europe. Utilizing his own movements, as well as components by such friends as Auguste [[Agassiz family|Agassiz]], Ernest Francillon, Constant [[Girard-Perregaux]], Jules Jeanneret, and Louis and Jules Courvoisier, Gallet began production of 30 new watch brands, most designed specifically to appeal to the taste of the America consumer. Within a short period, exports of Swiss watches to America rapidly increased, greatly expanding the reach of watchmakers whose previous market was limited only to the local economies. As a result, Leon L. Gallet’s American marketing activities helped to provide the needed capital for the watchmakers of the Jura region to industrialize, and successfully meet one of the greatest challenges in Swiss timekeeping’s history. == Léon L. Gallet Gallery == File: Leon_l_gallet_pocket_watch_movement_1879.jpg| Extra fine pocket watch movement by Léon L. Gallet (ca. 1879) – bi-metallic temperature compensation balance, Breguet style over-coil hairspring, patent chronometer regulator, solid gold jewel settings, wolf tooth winding, jeweled to the center. File: Leon_gallet_obituary_1899.jpg|Leon. L. Gallet Obituary - The New York Times, 11 May 1899 ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.galletwatch.com Official Gallet Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100126175844/http://www.nawcc.org/index.php/museumlibrary National Watch and Clock Museum] * [http://www.mih.ch/ Musée International d'Horlogerie] * [http://www.galletworld.com GalletWorld.com - The Gallet Information Resource] {{DEFAULTSORT:Gallet, Leon}} [[Category:1832 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:People from La Chaux-de-Fonds]] [[Category:Watchmakers (people)]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{infobox person | name = Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1906|08|21}} | birth_place = [[Enghien-les-Bains]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1996|04|11|1906|08|21}} | death_place = Paris, France | nationality = French | occupation = founder of [[publicis]] | relatives = [[Élisabeth Badinter]] <small>(daughter)</small> }} '''Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet''' (21 August 1906 – 11 April 1996) was a French advertising magnate best known as the founder of [[Publicis Groupe]]. Bleustein-Blanchet also invented radio advertising in France, helped create the first French opinion polls, introduced [[Édith Piaf]] to the French public, and fought with the [[Free French]] forces during World War II.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world/marcel-bleustein-blanchet-dies-paris-advertising-giant-was-89.html Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet Dies; Paris Advertising Giant Was 89]. ''The New York Times'' (13 April 1996). Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref> <ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituaries-marcel-bleusteinblanchet-1304631.html Obituaries: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet – People, News]. ''The Independent''. Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref>
The son of Abraham Bleustein, a Russian-Jewish furniture salesman in northern Paris, Marcel Bleustein left school at the age of 14 to help out in the family furniture business. He founded Publicis in 1926 in a small apartment above a butcher's shop. In 1935, he purchased Radio LL from the radio manufacturer [[Lucien Lévy]]. He renamed it Radio Cité, and introduced France's first news broadcasts as well as its first radio jingles. Radio Cité also helped launch singer [[Édith Piaf]].
In 1939, Marcel Bleustein married Sophie Vaillant, an English teacher who was the granddaughter of [[Edouard Vaillant]], a well-known 19th century Socialist politician. They had three daughters, including [[Elisabeth Badinter]], a prominent feminist writer and philosopher who chairs the supervisory board of Publicis Groupe. When the Second World War broke out, Marcel Bleustein's companies were confiscated by the German occupation forces as "Jewish properties". He joined the Resistance, took the code-name Blanchet, and was detached to serve as a co-pilot for the US [[Eighth Air Force]], flying bombing missions over France and Holland. When the war ended, he rebuilt Publicis from scratch, introducing the first opinion polls in France and developing the then-American fields of consumer research and brand analysis. [http://2.262.00515.X]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He retained his Resistance name of Blanchet, adding it legally to his original name. After the war, Mr. Bleustein-Blanchet reopened Publicis and, calling them on the phone himself, rapidly regained old and new clients, notably Shell, Colgate-Palmolive, L'oreal, Renault, Dim and many others. In 1957 he opened the first "Publicis Drugstore" on the ground level of Publicis' headquarters, 133 avenue des Champs Elysées, former location of the Astoria hotel. The "Drugstore" was a huge success and immediately became the rendez vous point of the cool parisian youth.
During the 1970s, under the leadership of Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet and his successor, [[Maurice Lévy (Publicis)|Maurice Lévy]], Publicis became an international communications group and is now the third largest communications group in the world.<ref>[http://adage.com/article/global-news/publicis-quarter-organic-revenue-growth-7-1/145176/ Publicis' Second-Quarter Organic Revenue Growth Is 7.1%]. ''Advertising Age'' (29 July 2010). Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref> In 2008, twelve years after his death, the [[American Advertising Federation]] announced that Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet would become the first non-American to be named to the [[Advertising Hall of Fame]].
