{{for|the Russian sledge hockey player|Vladimir Litvinenko (sledge hockey)}} {{Infobox person | image = Vladimir Stefanovich Litvinenko 2017.jpg | image_size = 180 | name = Vladimir Litvinenko | caption = | birth_name = Vladimir Stefanovich Litvinenko | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|8|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Stitzberg|first=Valery|url= http://old.redstar.ru/2002/11/30_11/1_02.html|title=Без крепкой экономики нет сильных Вооруженных сил|work=[[Krasnaya Zvezda]]|date=November 30, 2002|accessdate=March 3, 2016|language=ru}}</ref> Soviet Union | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Russian | residence = St. Petersburg, Russia | education = [[Saint Petersburg Mining University|Leningrad Mining Institute]] | occupation = [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] | known for = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = [[Olga Litvinenko]] | relatives = | website = }} '''Vladimir Stefanovich Litvinenko''' ({{lang-ru|Влади́мир Стефа́нович Литвине́нко}}, born 14 August 1955) is a [[Russia]]n academic, businessman and [[Vladimir Putin]]'s campaign manager.<ref name="Bureau">{{cite web | url=http://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/2012/03/02/the-fabulous-riches-of-putins-inner-circle/ | title=The fabulous riches of Putin’s inner circle | publisher=The Bureau Investigates | accessdate=June 7, 2012}}</ref> He is also rector of [[Saint Petersburg Mining University]] in [[St. Petersburg]].<ref name="Bureau"/>
==Career== Litvinenko has been the rector of Saint Petersburg Mining University since the 1990s. He oversaw Vladimir Putin's dissertation work in 1996, which is alleged to include significant amounts of [[plagiarism]] and is speculated perhaps to have not even been written by Putin (i.e. that he paid somebody to write it for him). Litvinenko has been criticised for not spotting the plagiarism.<ref name=cdi.org>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/2006-78-3a.cfm|title=It All Boils Down to Plagiarism|publisher=Cdi.org|date=2006-03-31|accessdate=2010-03-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806181040/http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/2006-78-3a.cfm|archive-date=2009-08-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} Clifford Gaddy: "Mr. Litvinenko -- who was directly involved in the dissertation, allegedly helped [Putin] choose the topic and was more or less the advisor for the dissertation -- is himself a member of the higher accreditation commission, which is the government-appointed body to be the watchdog over standards about degree-granting, dissertations and quality control for higher education in Russia. So it’s extra scandalous that he would be involved in this case of, at minimum, shoddiness and plagiarism, possibly something worse, which would be the literal purchase, either by money or political influence, of a dissertation by someone who didn’t actually do the work. That second point is not clear. I don’t have proof about that. All I have is proof about the plagiarism."</ref> According to his daughter Olga, Vladimir Litvinenko himself wrote the dissertation.<ref name="Ester-Maria"/>
Litvinenko was Putin's political campaign manager in 2000 and 2004.
On June 11, 2014, he was given an honorary doctorate by the [[Freiberg University of Mining and Technology]], Saxony, Germany.<ref name=Freiberg>{{cite web|url=http://tu-freiberg.de/en/presse/rector-of-the-st-petersburg-mining-institute-to-receive-an-honorary-doctorate|title=Rector of the St. Petersburg Mining Institute to receive an honorary doctorate|publisher=tu-freiberg.de|date=2014-06-11|accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref>
==Business career== Litvinenko owns nearly 15% of [[PhosAgro]], a [[phosphate]] mining company<ref name="Bureau"/> in the Arctic.<ref name="NY">{{cite news |last1=Kramer|first1=Andrew E.|last2=Herszenhornmarch |first2=David M.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/02/world/europe/ties-to-vladimir-putin-generate-fabulous-wealth-for-a-select-few-in-russia.html?pagewanted=3&_r=1&hp | title=Midas Touch in St. Petersburg: Friends of Putin Glow Brightly | work=The New York Times|date=March 1, 2012 | accessdate=June 7, 2012 | pages=3}}</ref> The mine had been at one time partly owned by [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]].<ref name="NY"/> He claims that he was paid in shares for some consulting that he did in 2004 and that this "did not contradict any laws".<ref name="NY"/>
Phosagro was floated on the [[London Stock Exchange]] in July 2011 and Litvinenko was listed among its new owners, as chairman.<ref name="NY"/> When Litvinenko owned 5%, the stock was worth about $260 million.<ref name="Bureau"/> In April 2014, he acquired a further 4.9% from [[Andrey Guryev]], who controls the company, for $269 million.<ref name=Bloomberg>{{cite news|last1=Fedorinova|first1=Yuliya|title=Putin Campaigner Buys $269 Million Phosagro Stake From Guryevs|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-04-28/putin-campaigner-buys-269-million-phosagro-stake-from-guryevs|accessdate=25 May 2015|work=Bloomberg|date=28 April 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Litvinenko has a daughter, [[Olga Litvinenko|Olga]], born in 1983,<ref name="Ester-Maria">{{cite web | url=http://ester-maria.com/olga | title=Ольга Литвиненко | publisher=Ester-Maria.com | accessdate=June 8, 2012|language=ru}}</ref> who used to be a member of the [[Legislative Assembly of Saint Petersburg]].<ref name="Daughter">{{cite web | url=http://www.rosbalt.ru/piter/2012/04/24/973803.html | title=Дочь Владимира Литвиненко: У моего отца "синдром Ивана Грозного" | publisher=Rosbalt.ru |date=April 24, 2012| accessdate=June 8, 2012|language=ru}}</ref> In May 2010 Vladimir and his wife were looking after Olga's daughter [[Ester-Maria Litvinenko]] (born in 2009), and refused to give her back to Olga.<ref name="Daughter"/> Olga has described this as a [[kidnapping]] and has instigated legal proceedings to get her daughter back. Olga describes her father as "the richest rector in Russia" and an "[[Russian oligarchs|oligarch]]" ("самый богатый ректор России, олигарх"<ref name="Ester-Maria"/>). When Olga fled the country in summer 2011, Vladimir reported to the police that Olga and her other son, Mikhail, had been kidnapped and his daughter's assets were frozen.<ref name="Daughter"/> According to Olga, all lawyers defending her were arrested and sentenced.<ref>[http://telewizjarepublika.pl/litvinenko-putin-chce-pokazac-europie-ze-prawo-rosji-obowiazuje-wszedzie,13502.html Litvinenko: Putin wants to show Europe that Russia's law applies everywhere], telewizjarepublika.pl, November 5th 2014</ref>

[[Order of the British Empire]] }} '''William Brenton Boggs IV''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC|OBE}} (December 18, 1918 – July 7, 2011),{{cite web|url=http://v1.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/Deaths.20110113.93253735/BDAStory/BDA/deaths|title=Obituary|work=The Globe and Mail}} was a pioneering [[Canada|Canadian]] leader in military and commercial aviation. ==Early years== Born in [[Douglas, Arizona]], United States, on December 18, 1918, William Brenton (Bill) Boggs relocated to [[Noranda, Quebec]] with his parents in 1927. He graduated from [[McGill University]], mechanical engineering, and became an Engineering Officer of the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] in 1940. During his [[World War II]] service, he notably served as Senior Engineering Officer of 331 Wing of Wellington bombers dispatched to Tunisia, North Africa to support the Allied landings in Sicily and Italy, for which contributions he was appointed to the [[Order of the British Empire]] (O.B.E.) in 1944. ==Civilian career== Boggs' early civilian career included positions with [[Air Canada|Trans-Canada Airlines]] (1945-1950) and [[Canadair]] (1950-1957) before he joined Can-Car, a subsidiary of [[Hawker Siddeley Canada]], and became vice president of Hawker Siddley. In 1965, he became President of [[de Havilland Canada]] (DHC). During this term, he was involved with the development of the 30-seat [[Dash-7]] commuter aircraft. He then became President and eventually Chairman of Canada Systems Group (CSG), and, in 1983, President and CEO of The Canadian Data and Professional Service Organization. Boggs was invited back to DHC in 1984, as Chairman, President and CEO, when that company was being prepared for privatization. When the [[Boeing Company]] bought DHC in 1986, Boggs became Vice Chairman of [[Boeing Canada]]. In 1987 he became Chairman of Field Aviation Holdings Inc. He remained there until he retired in 1995. ==Honours and legacy== In addition to being made an [[Order of the British Empire|Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] in 1944, Boggs was invested as an [[Order of Canada|Officer into the Order of Canada]] in 1988.{{OCC|2446}} He became a Fellow of the Canadian Aeronautics and Space Institute (CASI) in 1967 and served twice as Chairman of the Aerospace Industries Association of Canada (AIAC) (1967–68; 1987–88). In 1983 he was named Fellow of the Canadian School of Management. In 2003, he was inducted into [[Canada's Aviation Hall of Fame]]. ==References== * Oswald, Mary, ''They Led the Way'', Wetaskiwin: Canada's Aviation Hall of Fame, 1999. {{ISBN|0-9684843-0-1}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cahf.ca Hall of Fame site] {{DEFAULTSORT:Boggs, William}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:American emigrants to Canada]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]] [[Category:Canadian Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:People from Douglas, Arizona]] [[Category:People from Rouyn-Noranda]]
